newsitem.title: GERMANY: Deutsche Telekom talks with AOL continue.
newsitem.headline: Deutsche Telekom talks with AOL continue.

text.p: Deutsche Telekom AG said on Wednesday it is still in discussions with the German media group Bertelsmann AG and the U.S. online service provider America Online about a possible alliance.

The alliance would involve Telekom's online services T-Online and AOL Europe, a spokesman for Telekom told Reuters, who denied an earlier magazine report that Telekom wanted to ally T-Online to software group Microsoft Corp.
"The discussions are continuing," the Telekom spokesman said, but would give no details as to what stage the discussions were at.

Telekom said that it would be announcing a cooperation agreement with Microsoft in coming weeks at the CeBIT computer fair in Hanover, but said the announcement had no relevance on competition grounds.
In November 1995 Telekom and Bertelsmann announced a agreement on principle to ally their online services, which would include some form of exchange of mutual holdings.
A spokesman for the Bertelsmann group in Guetersloh said that its negotiations with Telekom were experiencing problems on competition grounds.

Bertelsmann said that German cartel authorities had indicated there could be problems if market leaders T-Online and AOL Europe, which is a operated by Bertelsmann and AOL, sought to forge an alliance.
One of the points of issue is how much of a stake Telekom is allowed to take in the alliance. Telekom has sought around 30 percent.
The German Federal Cartel Office said that its president, Dieter Wolf, said some time ago that it would examine any proposed cooperation between T-Online and AOL.
The watchdog said that it had received no further concrete plans from the parties involved.
